image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in Boston, Mass., March 30, 1910; educated in the Boston public schools and Lincoln Preparatory School; attended Suffolk University; registrar of vital statistics for the city of Boston; during the Second World War was special agent in the Counter-intelligence, attached to the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division in the South Pacific; member of the Massachusetts general court for ten years; member of the Massachusetts house of representatives for four years, serving as assistant majority leader; vice chairman of the Massachusetts Democratic State committee for four years; elected as a Democrat to the Eighty-sixth and to the nine succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1959-January 3, 1979); was not a candidate for reelection in 1978 to the Ninety-sixth Congress; was a resident of Milton, Mass. until his death in Boston, Mass. on October 13, 1983; interment at Milton Cemetery, Milton, Mass.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: James A. Burke, Democratic Representative from Massachusetts. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.
U.S. Congress. House. Memorial Services for James Anthony Burke. 98th Congress, 1st Sess., 1983. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1984.

researchRecord.name: 1958-1979, about 165,000 items.
researchRecord.description: Congressional files for the 86th through the 95th Congress. Part of the collection is open for research.

researchRecord.name: In the John F. Kennedy Oral History Collection, 1976, 10 pages.
researchRecord.description: An oral history interview with former Rep. James A. Burke conducted on April 13, 1976. In the interview, Burke discusses John F. Kennedy’s (JFK) congressional and presidential campaigns, and JFK’s time in Congress, among other issues. The interview is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: In the John F. Kennedy Oral History Collection, 1976, 4 pages.
researchRecord.description: The second part of an oral history interview with former Rep. James A. Burke conducted on April 14, 1976. In the interview, Burke discusses John F. Kennedy’s personality and political skill, among other issues. The interview is available in the repository and online.
